Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES: A Networked Improvement Community for Broadening the Participation of Black and Latino Youth in Computational Careers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Designing for Diversity will establish a national Networked Improvement Community (NIC) of maker spaces and fab labs serving Black and Latino high school students and specializing in computational making programs. The project will be led by the New York Hall of Science, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and a national leadership team representing universities, cultural organizations, corporations, foundations and leaders in the Maker Movement. Using a NIC methodology, the partners will identify the most promising mechanisms for ensuring that participation in computational making programs has a significant impact on participants' choices to pursue STEM focused internships, post-secondary education, and career paths. The project will extend the NIC methodology into the informal learning community, which is in need of research methods that are both rigorous and accommodating of the institutional complexities of building and sustaining high-quality informal learning environments, and it will contribute to the literature on the impact of maker spaces and fab labs in underserved communities on the diversification of the STEM pipeline. The project will also pave the way for the development of a more fully-developed network of computational making programs across the country and a more comprehensive research initiative that will influence best practices in maker spaces and fab labs and foster perceptions of the value and impact of maker experiences on young people's readiness for future educational experiences and careers.

The project builds on research indicating that computational making - programs that combine the making of artifacts with computational tools and techniques - is a powerful strategy for engaging underrepresented students in STEM learning. However, participation in such programs will not necessarily lead students to take concrete steps toward computationally-rich STEM careers in which they are currently under-represented. A range of research suggests that computational making programs need to explicitly design for and address the socio-emotional dimensions of these learning experiences in order for them to become stepping stones into these careers. Designing for Diversity will work with a network of maker programs serving high needs Black and Latino high school students to address these learning factors. During this pilot, the leadership team will accomplish three tasks: (1) establish a common framework, shared measurement objectives and guidelines that will be used to identify, recruit and support participant maker programs and their local partners; (2) develop and coordinate the NIC's capacity for scaling and disseminating its work by connecting the research efforts to broader national initiatives; and (3) recruit, train, and collect baseline data on the Designing for Diversity NIC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Designing for Diversity INCLUDES Launch Pilot project established a national Networked Improvement Community (NIC) of maker spaces and fab labs serving Black and Latino high school aged youth and specializing in computational making programs. The project built on research indicating that computational making—programs that combine the making of artifacts with computational tools and techniques—is a powerful strategy for engaging underrepresented students in STEM learning. However, participation in such programs is not necessarily likely to lead students to take concrete steps toward computationally-rich STEM careers.

Therefore, NIC partners worked together to identify the most promising mechanisms for ensuring that participation in computational making programs has a significant impact on participants’ choices to pursue STEM focused internships, post-secondary education, and career paths. The project was further unique in that it extended the NIC methodology (which has historically focused on formal education) into informal learning communities, which are in need of research methods that are both rigorous and accommodating of the institutional complexities of building and sustaining high-quality informal learning environments.

The project team accomplished three tasks: (1) establish a common framework, shared measurement objectives, and guidelines that will be used to identify, recruit, and support participant maker programs and their local partners; (2) develop and coordinate the NIC’s capacity for scaling and disseminating its work by connecting the research efforts to broader national initiatives; and (3) recruit, train, and collect baseline data on the Designing for Diversity NIC. Specifically, our shared PROBLEM STATEMENT is: “Underrepresented youth experience challenges that prevent them from discovering, exploring, and developing pathways to computational careers.” Our preliminary common AIM is: By the first day of [DATE TBD] we will increase the amount of internship and academic opportunities in STEM/C fields for high-school age youth engaged in out-of-school-time computational programs by 30%.”

With input from an advisory board of national experts, we identified 35 possible sites. PIs and senior advisors conducted interviews with sites and we used the following criteria to guide us in making final selections: program longevity (minimum of five years) and stability, including a secure base of local funding; significant portion of youth served are black and Latino high school students; focus on computational thinking, computer science, and/or computational making programs; and demonstrated interest on the part of the Executive Director for engaging in a collaborative research project.

The selected maker space sites were: the Bay Area Video Coalition (San Francisco, CA); the Lower Eastside Girls Club (New York, NY); California State University at Bakersfield Fab Lab (Bakersfield, CA); South End Technology Center (Boston, MA); Assemble (Pittsburgh, PA); Mouse & CODE Interactive (New York, NY); NYSCI Maker Space (Corona, NY); and Digital Harbor Foundation (Baltimore, MD). The demographic and gender breakdown of high school students being served through the eight programs is as follows: Race/Ethnicity: Multiracial – 9%; Asian – 20%; White/Caucasian – 27%; African American/Black – 28%;  and Latinx/Hispanic – 32%. Gender: female – 55%; male – 40%; and transgender – 15%.
